description: Cityview Classic Cars is proud to off this beautiful low mileage original 1972 Buick GS 350. You have to see this car to believe it. It has one repaint and many options including very cold AC. Sitting in the driver seat of this car your are surrounded by 1972. And if this is what 1972 felt like give me more please. Powered buy the original 350 cid V8 and Turbo 350 transmission and Posi-Trac rear end you are driving a confident car and you can feel it. Is it the fastest no is it stylish comfortable and does it turn heads absolutely. The options include Power Steering Power Brakes A/C AM/FM Radio Factory Gauge package with Tachometer W21 Custom Trim Package and more from the factory. Comes with paperwork including original window sticker. Seriously it would be a mistake not to buy this car. For more pictures visit www.cityviewclassiccars.com for more information or to just pull the trigger call us at 817-292-4477.Financing is available.

Has an ID plate, but no title.
Car is sold AS IS.

1952 Buick Super Riviera-Land Speed Race Car “Bombshell Betty”
Gas Competition Coupe vintage engine class speed record
This one-of-a-kind car has six Bonneville Salt Flats Land Speed Records under her belt with a top record of 165.735!
At the 2009 Bonneville Nationals Speed Week, it set a record speed of 130.838 mph in the XO/GCC class
At the 2009 Bonneville Nationals World Finals, it set a record of 134.054 mph
At the 2010 Bonneville Nationals World Finals, it set a record of 141.821 mph
At the 2012 Bonneville Nationals Speed Week, it set the Land Speed Record in the XO/GCC class, at 162.481 mph
At the 2012 Bonneville Nationals World Finals, it reached 165.380 mph
At the 2013 Bonneville Nationals Speed Week, it won the Land Speed Record in XO/GCC class, reaching 165.735 mph
Created by sculptor Jeff Brock
Previous owner was renowned photographer Peter Lik
Car gets her nickname from the bombshell air intake above the hood
Powered by a 340HP 320 CID straight eight-cylinder engine from a 1950 Buick Roadmaster with dual carburetion, aftermarket pistons and a solid lifter camshaft
Borg-Warner Super T-10 four-speed manual transmission
Ford nine-inch rear end with Traction-Lok and 2.73:1 gearing
Powered by racing fuel with a four-gallon tank next to the engine block
Documentation includes five trophies, Event Record copy, Southern California Timing Association Official Vehicle Log Book and official licenses

If you're seeking one of the ultimate automotive conversation pieces of modern automotive history, you can stop looking. For a unique bit of rolling sculpture, complete with a legitimate history of Bonneville records. MotoeXotica Classic Cars is proud to present the famous “Bombshell Betty”. We at MotoeXotica are hard core car guys with a little bit of art backgrounds so we totally appreciate the art of Bombshell Betty, built and raced by sculptor Jeff Brock and then sold to renowned landscape photographer Peter Lik, we are all so in love with Betty!

Bombshell Betty is 1952 Buick Super Riviera-Land Speed Race Car (Gas Competition Coupe vintage engine). With an sculpted sheet metal body, the car holds six Land Speed World Records. The engine is a 340HP 320 CID straight eight from a 1950 Buick Roadmaster and the top custom intake manifold is from Hart's Collision-Racing Shop with a Jegs-Quick-Fuel 750cm racing carburetor. Betty currently has a twin carburetor setup, runs on racing fuel and has a four-gallon fuel tank next to the engine block. She also sports aftermarket pistons and a solid lifter camshaft from Automotive Machine Service in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Linked to the engine is a Borg-Warner Super T-10 four-speed manual transmission. At the back is a nine-inch Ford rear end lifted from a 1973 Thunderbird that has Traction-Lok and 2.73:1 gearing.

Created by sculptor and photographer Jeff Brock, who was born and raised in Flint, Michigan, Buick's headquarters during the height of its ability and prowess. He later moved to the southwestern part of the country, where he reportedly found a 1952 Buick Super Riviera at an old sawmill near Phoenix, Arizona in 2008 (original photo in gallery). He purchased the car and had it transported to his shop near Santa Fe, New Mexico, where it sat untouched until June of the following year.

Inspired by watching the Fastest Indian movie with Anthony Hopkins starring, Brock and his assistants worked 10–12 hours a day, often seven days a week, and as a result they built a car in record short terms. The contribution to the Bombshell Betty construction was also made by Jeff's wife, Star York, and Doug Anderson mechanic from Albuquerque, who helped with the high-performance units and parts construction.

In less than two months, Brock and his crew of volunteers worked around the clock to prepare the car for entry into that year's Speed Week event, which takes place in August. Outside, Brock and crew made many changes to prepare the car for racing on the salt flats. He inverted a truck's front bumper to use as Betty's prow, and he created the rockers and fender skirts for aerodynamic reasons while trying to maintain at least a modicum of Buick styling cues. The car does not have brakes. They chopped eight inches out of the roof and raised the rear shelf to meet the deck. A custom windscreen was created but the car has no backlight or taillamps for a better coefficient of drag. Helping that Cd are the headlight covers, inverted bucket headlamp assemblies sprung from a 1930s Chevrolet. Under the car is a full belly pan, a 1968 front axle assembly from a Chevrolet van narrowed to fit between the fender skirts and allow for movement. Finally, Betty gets her nickname from an air intake that is fitted within a bombshell.

In 2009, at the Bonneville Nationals Speed Week, she set the Land Speed Record in XO class (pre-1960 OHV inline engines)/GCC or Gas-powered Competition Coupes, reaching 130.838 mph. The same year at the Bonneville Nationals World Finals, it won for Land Speed Record XO/GCC, reaching 134.054 mph. Speed Week is typically in August while the World Finals occur in September or October. In 2010, at the Bonneville Nationals World Finals, it won the Land Speed Record XO/GCC, reaching 141.821 mph. In 2012, at the Bonneville Nationals Speed Week, it won the Land Speed Record XO/GCC, reaching 162.481 mph. In 2012 at the Bonneville Nationals World Finals, it won the Land Speed Record XO/GCC, reaching 165.380 mph. In 2013, at the Bonneville Nationals Speed Week, it won the Land Speed Record XO/GCC, reaching 165.735 mph. Betty's previous owner was the renowned photographer Peter Lik.
Documentation includes five trophies, Event Record copy, Southern California Timing Association Official Vehicle Log Book.
This car is currently located at our facility in St. Louis, Missouri. It is sold as is, where is, on a bill of sale only!
Team owner / constructor / pilot: Jeff Brock
Team: Ted Seeley, Mike Oestreich, Star York, Dennis Little, Sean Cridland, Sandra One Feather. Team Manager: Sergio Juarez

. It's in excellent mechanical condition and would be a great driver. I consider this vehicle 85% restored. 350 HO engine with a .260 cam. Less than 5,000 miles on rebuild. New tires. Factory A/C, but does not work. Rust in trunk. Custom grill and air intakes. Fiberglass hood. Body clean/straight with no damage. Interior 90% for the year. Automatic.
**Special Note**

We recently took this vehicle on an 8 hour road trip and experienced zero problems. Any 1972 vehicle capable of making that trip (and not just once) is in fnatastic condition. This car would be a great daily driver, something to take to car shows, or just a small resto project.

1963 Buick LeSabre. We are a film company, and are currently reducing our vehicle inventory. Own a '63 done up as a hotrod. A few notable features: very nice wheels and rims, full custom exhaust, all original chrome, clean/straight body with no damage, dynacoated floor pans, 401 nailhead engine rebuilt with .260 cam, new weather stripping. There is less than 2,000 miles on the rebuild. Paint is 75% condition. Overall car rating 90%. Car sounds great, looks great, and drives great! Not many of these around. Definitely a different eye catcher.

1986 Buick Grand National

When Buick introduced the Grand National the Muscle Car field was anemic at best, heck a Vette only had 185 horses.  With the advent of multi-port fuel injection and intercooled turbo chargers the required ''ponies to play'' equation was pumped up considerably and Buick, of all makes, became the benchmark.  With 245 horses the 3.8 Liter 6 began to gobble up many a previous competitor on the track and street.  Not only did you get loads more power and torque in the muscle bound Regal, you still got all the creature comforts Buick had become known for in your father's era, not to mention styling that was pretty avant garde for the times.  This great example, with only 41k miles. in the preferred Black cloaking, has all the power options not to mention a rare sliding sun roof for those of us that still have hair to blow around.  Here is your chance to harken back to those days when gas was well under a dollar and cassettes were the mainstay of your music collection.
Features
Original 3.8 Liter Turbo Charged and Intercooled V6
4 Speed Automatic Transmission with overdrive
Only 45k original miles
Factory correct and full functioning Air Conditioning
Original Factory T Top Roof
Nice correct Black Paint with Monochromatic bumpers
Correct Gray and Black Bucket Seats GM seatbelts front and rear and full console
Grand National Chrome and Black Rally Wheels
Newer Cooper Cobra P235/60R15 Black Wall Radials
Full factory instrumentation with boost indicator and tach
Leather wrapped tilt steering wheel
Factory cruise control
Twilight Sentinel headlight system
Original AMFM Cassette radio with equalizer in the dash
Dual outside color keyed racing mirrors
Full correct trunk trim with spare and jack
Full Performance Tuned Exhaust with correct Tips
Nicely detailed engine bay
Power Windows and Locks
We don't see many Grand Nationals and to find one with these options is a real score
